Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing the Origins of the Colorado River: An Integrative Study of the Miocene-Pliocene Bouse Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite nearly a century of study, the conditions that controlled initiation of the mighty Colorado River remain poorly understood and vigorously debated. This project seeks to reconstruct the origins of the Colorado River through multidisciplinary study of the Bouse Formation, a complex sedimentary deposit that accumulated in the lower reaches of the valley during river initiation between ~ 6.0 and 4.5 million years ago. The study benefits from collaborations among university professors and students, state and federal agency scientists, a county museum paleontologist, and a local high school teacher.

The PI's will use integrated datasets to determine if the Bouse Formation formed in a brackish marine estuary or a large inland lake isolated from the ocean, a key distinction for understanding the origins of the river. This study also explores when and how waters of the Colorado River first reached the sea. Hypotheses will be tested through study of stratigraphic architecture, sedimentology, carbonate geochemistry (including C, O, Sr, and S isotopes), and geochronology. Hypothesis tests emphasize cross-correlation of radiogenic and stable isotope data with major and trace-element chemistry in a precise stratigraphic and structural framework. The PI's will run two workshops: one to engage a broad community of geoscientists, and one to plan a future scientific drilling proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bouse Formation is a thin but important and enigmatic sedimentary succession along the Lower Colorado River. Its importance is that it provides one of the only sedimentary records of the first arrival of the continental-scale Colorado River system to the sea at the Gulf of California. Its enigmas have resulted in persistent debates for several decades: what is its age, was it deposited in marine basins or lakes, and was its deposition affected by tectonic movements. A multidisciplinary collaborative team from University of New Mexico, University of New Mexico, University of Arizona, the United States Geological Survey and the Arizona Geological Survey addressed these debates using new tools: precise dating of tiny sanidine sand grains in the sandstones to constrain the age, detailed study of the basin setting using information from the sedimentary architecture, fossils, and carbonate geochemistry, study of minor faults and variations in sedimentary thickness to establish earth movements during and after Bouse deposition, and geodynamic studies of amount of uplift that could have been due to erosion, sediment loading, and upwelling mantle. Debates persist about some details and campfire discussions involved animated discussions, but our group's new data are leading ever closer to consensus that resolves most of these issues, as follows. 1) The Colorado River reached the sea in the Gulf of California 4.9 million years ago (Ma); this is refined from previous estimates of 6.0-5.3 Ma. This means that Grand Canyon was carved in the past 5 Ma. The first arriving waters that deposited the basal Bouse travertine (aka tufa) came from the north, were fed by springs and groundwater leaking out of the Colorado Plateau and spilling progressively southwards in a series of lake basins, and were deposited as a limestone encrustation on the pre-existing irregular basin topography. The travertines contain charophyte fossils indicating the earliest waters were fresh, not seawater. In the southern Bouse basin (Blythe basin), seawater entered the basin and mixed with these lake waters in an estuary-like setting. Marine deposition is shown by tidal sedimentary structures and marine fossils. The path of the southward-extending embryonic Colorado River followed N-S fault- bounded basins in which thicker Bouse deposits accumulated causing subsidence feedbacks. These faults are linked to NW- trending strike slip faults and, together, record a wide deforming region from southern Nevada to southern California and Arizona. This deforming part of the continent inboard of the San Andreas fault has accommodated about 18 km of the plate movement between the North American and Pacific plates and still continues to deform today as shown by satellite measurements. The region was also broadly uplifted a few hundred meters by upwelling buoyant mantle under the Chocolate Mountains and Gulf of California. The success of this project in resolving important earth science controversies was due to the numerous investigators applying their subdisciplines with an intent to honor different datasets and viewpoints.

The project was accompanied by extensive dissemination of new knowledge via publication of open-access peer-reviewed journal articles as well as during lively professional meeting presentations and discussions. A Geological Society of America Thompson Field Forum brought together key scientists to showcase and debate the new evidence. Outreach to the public was also extensive and involved public geoscience meetings at Grand Canyon National Park, with additional meetings planned for 2020 and 2021. New information is also being added to the website of Grand Canyon National Park and included in training for Park interpreters. Successful efforts to promote diversity in the geosciences were accomplished by student mentoring of minority students and women, by work with local high school teachers, and by a joint agreement with the Colorado River Indian Tribes (CRIT) that consists of four tribes: Mohave, Chemehuevi, Hopi, and Navajo. Not all of the 'Bouse controversies' are resolved, in part because of limited information on the subsurface characteristics of the Bouse Formation. The last part of the project (late 2019) involved a workshop among both the projects PIs, a still wider group of scientists, and CRIT representatives, to design a drilling project to address remaining questions such as: how much of the basins were marine and how much non-marine, how and when did carbonate basin deposits transition to sands and gravels of the arriving Colorado River in each basin, how, in more detail, are the fault networks accommodating ongoing deformation of this part of the plate, and how good are the Bouse aquifers for water yield to supply farming in this region.
